Academic and Technological Sources of Evera

Evera aligns digital person reconstruction with the Library of the Eternals, uniting peer-reviewed knowledge and an autonomous compute stack.

These partners anchor the Evera methodology and the OpenAI test environment before every model migrates into our sealed infrastructure.

Academic institutions

Universities contribute archives, corpora, and philology that make each digital reconstruction verifiable. Their scholarship keeps the Library of the Eternals accountable and ethically grounded.

  • Harvard We use corpora and publications to verify quotes and context of the 'Eternals'.
  • MIT Modeling relies on MIT AI & linguistics research.
  • Stanford Leverage Stanford's interdisciplinary research on memory and cognitive systems.
  • Oxford Source of critical editions/translations for ancient 'Eternals'.
  • Cambridge Used for reference validation and dictionaries.
  • ETH ZÃ¼rich A foundation for analytical psychology reconstructions.
  • Princeton Critical editions/monographs for context.
  • Sorbonne Linguistic and cultural sources.
  • Toronto Text corpora and stylistic analysis methods.
  • Athens Key partner for Greek text variants.
  • Harvard-Yenching Provides archives and grants on Eastern humanistic traditions.
  • Philemon Sources for Jung reconstructions.
  • UNESCO Ethical and heritage frameworks.
  • Academia Sinica Corpus data and linguistics.

Technological platforms

Technology partners supply compute, safety-first LLMs, and deployment tooling. OpenAI remains the test environment before every model is transferred into Everaâs autonomous stack.

  • OpenAI Used as a bridge before full migration to Evera infra.
  • DeepMind Rely on research on models & memory.

  • Stability AI Visual illustrations for dialogues.

  • Supabase Store TMA users & events.
  • Vercel Hosting API/functions and static pages.
  • Cloudflare Edge cache & protection for speed.
  • GitHub Repos for methodology and build.
  • Telegram Interface & distribution of Evera dialogues.
